Description: Three national consumer reporting agencies agreed to a total of $2.5 million in payments as part of settlements of allegations that they each violated provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act by failing to maintain a toll-free telephone number with personnel accessible to consumers during normal business hours.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against Equifax, Inc., TransUnion, and their subsidiaries for deceiving consumers about the usefulness and actual cost of credit scores they sold to consumers. The companies were also accused of luring consumers into costly recurring payments for credit-related products with false promises.
TransUnion agreed to pay $8 million to settler allegations that it mistakenly identified thousands of U.S. consumers as having criminal records or being on terrorist watch lists.
Private Litigation Case Title: Patel v. Trans Union, LLC et al

Description: Experian, TransUnion, and Equifax agreed to pay a total of $7.175 million to settle allegations they engaged in deceptive marketing activities by signing up customers to credit monitoring services they were unaware of, and also produced credit reports that failed to properly verify information and did not take into account Mississippi law. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.

Equifax Information Services, Experian Information Solutions and TransUnion agreed to pay a total of $6 million to settle multistate allegations relating to their handling of consumer disputes about credit report errors, monitoring and disciplining data furnishers (providers of credit reporting information), accuracy in consumer credit reports, and the marketing of credit monitoring products to consumers who call the credit reporting agencies to dispute information on their credit report. The settlement did not specify how the $6 million cost would be split among the three companies; we assume each paid $2 million.
